title: 107_hr5426
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fort Donelson National Battlefield Expansion Act of 2002". The Fort Donelson National Battlefield commemorates the Battle of Fort Donelson in February 1862 and the campaign led by General Ulysses S. Grant and Admiral Andrew H. Foote resulting in the capture of Fort Donelson by Union forces. The boundaries include the site of Fort Donelson, Fort Donelson National Cemetery in Tennessee, and Fort Heiman in Kentucky. The Fort Donelson National Battlefield, commemorating the Battle of Fort Donelson in February 1862, includes the site of Fort Donelson, Fort Donelson National Cemetery in Tennessee, and Fort Heiman in Kentucky. The battlefield may expand to include land acquired under section 3. Land acquisition related to Fort Donelson National Battlefield under section 3 may expand the battlefield to include additional land. The Secretary of the Interior has the authority to acquire land, interests, and improvements for the Fort Donelson National Battlefield through purchase, donation, or exchange with willing owners. This includes land within specified boundaries and outside areas identified as part of the battlefield. Upon acquisition of land or interests in subsection (b)(2), the Secretary of the Interior will revise the boundaries of the Fort Donelson National Battlefield to include the acquired property, with a limitation of 2,000 acres for the total area of the park. The Secretary of the Interior will administer Fort Donelson National Battlefield in accordance with applicable laws. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of the Interior will cooperate to protect and interpret Civil War resources in the Land Between the Lakes National Recreation Area. Obsolete provisions will be repealed. Repeals of laws from 1928, 1937, and 1960 related to national parks and amendments to the Act of March 26, 1928, including changes to the Secretary of War designation. The Act of August 30, 1937 is amended to change "Fort Donelson National Military Park" to "Fort Donelson National Battlefield" and replace "War Department" with "Department of the Army". The Act of August 30, 1937 is amended to change "Fort Donelson National Military Park" to "Fort Donelson National Battlefield" and remove the restriction on the total area commemorating the battle of Fort Donelson.
